title-group.article-title: Defining Landscape Painting in Nineteenth-Century American Critical Discourse. Or, Should Art 'Deal in Wares the Age Has Need of'?

abstract.p: The critical reception of Asher B. Durand's 1855 painting In the Woods sets out some of the preeminent concerns and terms of debate for the genre, and for art in general in the years preceding the Civil War. The painting divided critical opinion. Employing common aesthetic criteria, the opposing writers all took up the question of whether a landscape painting should dwell on factual details. The commentary, however, expressed aesthetic opinions in a vocabulary of labour, materialism, and commodities. Consequently, I consider the relationship between the form of the painting and the partisanship of its reception, how we might read the uneasy and indirect, yet evident rhetorical movement between aesthetic terms and economic ones, and what the implications were for the definition of landscape painting. Arguing that In the Woods offered the material substance of the world as a value by itself, and a mode of viewing that installed significance on the surface, I suggest that the debate was over the larger role of art. Would representation be defined by materialism? Should art, with its lofty status as a transcendent value, sanction by adopting, the mode of vision utilised by the commodity?
